body:
I am trying to install R to test on my computer, & will be reaching as soon as possible after testing.

Thanks.

ok, then let me have a look what's going on here and merge this once the remaining issues are fixed. Thanks @j143.

ok thanks again @j143 - here is just a quick summary of what was missing
* Fix of R and dml scripts (e.g., license in one R script, conversion to vectors)
* Cleanup of function objects, with support for long-long, double-double inputs (now with proper int semantics to match R results)
* Add missing scalar-scalar and matrix-scalar compiler and runtime support (incl fixes for the existing AND, OR, XOR operators)

From a style perspective, in the future, please leave the individual imports - using the wildcard makes it harder to resolve if there are multiple wildcards.

Hi Matthias,

Sorry about the wildcard import that seems to be automatic in my ide, I will make sure that I will follow your code style. I will go through the changeset once more, so that things will be clearer to me. 

Thanks.  cc @mboehm7

Hi @niketanpansare , review shouldn't take more that 10 mins, promise!. 

simply,
1. the algorithm steps are [in textbook](https://github.com/apache/systemml/pull/711#issuecomment-353591028) as it is.
2. the derivatives in step 4, & step 6 were found in the text, but they are correct.

Thanks.
LGTM. Thanks @j143 üëç

Thanks for reviewing this first script, 
I will try my best for, 
1. every script to be accompanied by a test.
2. If it is a full fledged script such as classification, then I will test it on sample data before review.
3. I will try to add, work for the documentation for the each script that I add. 

Thanks a lot, :)  cc @niketanpansare

thanks for working on this @j143 - I would recommend to get your local junit tests running first because it will greatly improve your productivity.

Hi @mboehm7 , Can you please comment on this simple xor operation, & test files. I tried running the test locally, I am missing out something.

In the meanwhile, I will try to figure out. Thanks.
Hi @niketanpansare , can this be merged. (I am only a contributor, now!). Thanks a lot.
I'm currently traveling but I'll have a closer looks once I'm back.
test this jenkins

I would recommend that you contact Prithvi or Sasha as they have worked on http://apache.github.io/systemml/algorithms-descriptive-statistics.html scripts and use  https://github.com/apache/systemml/blob/master/scripts/algorithms/bivar-stats.dml and https://github.com/apache/systemml/blob/master/scripts/algorithms/Univar-Stats.dml as reference :)

For comparison, if we set `rank=10` for  the first fully connected layer in Lenet, the memory budgets for the weights are as follows:
```
+-----+---------------+--------------+--------------------+---------+-----------+---------+--------------------+
| Name|           Type|        Output|              Weight|     Bias|        Top|   Bottom|Memory* (train/test)|
+-----+---------------+--------------+--------------------+---------+-----------+---------+--------------------+
....
|  ip1|   InnerProduct| (, 512, 1, 1)|[3136 X 10], [10 ...|[1 X 512]|        ip1|    pool2|                20/2|
....
+-----+---------------+--------------+--------------------+---------+-----------+---------+--------------------+
```

instead of 
```
+-----+---------------+--------------+------------+---------+-----------+---------+--------------------+
| Name|           Type|        Output|      Weight|     Bias|        Top|   Bottom|Memory* (train/test)|
+-----+---------------+--------------+------------+---------+-----------+---------+--------------------+
....
|  ip1|   InnerProduct| (, 512, 1, 1)|[3136 X 512]|[1 X 512]|        ip1|    pool2|              797/13|
....
+-----+---------------+--------------+------------+---------+-----------+---------+--------------------+
```

The assumptions here is that we avoid the generation of  intermediate `W` matrix in low-rank affine layer. The performance on the validation set is comparable to the numbers in [Caffe2DML's beginner's guide](http://apache.github.io/systemml/beginners-guide-caffe2dml) (but not the test set):

**1. let us consider `r^2(x, x')` in the below formula:**
 for given dimension `d`, the the combination(substract!) of each element with every other element.

**2. for example:** 
`X = matrix(rows=5, cols=6);` as in the script.
for 1st dimension, `d=1`
1. `X(1,d) - X(1,d)` will be the `(1,1)`th element
2. `X(1,d) - X(2,d)` will be the `(1,2)`th element
3. `X(2,d) - X(1,d)` will be the `(2,1)`th element and so on..

@j143 - the issues is correctly raised because of the wrong new xor template `"    double %TMP% = %IN1% ^ %IN2%;\n"`. Java's ^ operator is an bitwise xor, which is only defined over integer inputs and hence you get the error. Please simply fix the template (see the vector operations). Furthermore, please fix the tests (all three cases and multiple operations, otherwise there is no potential for fusion).

@niketanpansare, @dusenberrymw thank for your feedback. Will make the necessary changes shortly.

thanks for the update @j143 , but the sparse vector operations still appear to produce incorrect results. You can recognize them by an `int[] aix` in the method signature. Please follow the two-pass approach I described in my previous comments. To reiterate, the issue is that you cannot initialize the output to a constant because the output for a zero (i.e., non-existing value) in the sparse input depends on the value of the other side, which requires a pass if it's a dense vector. Also, please don't return null in `vectXorWrite`. 

Let do an example to make sure, we're on the same page: Lets assume you want to compute `C = xor(A, B)`, where A  is a sparse vector `[0, 2, 0, 0, 1]` and B is a dense vector `[1, 3, 0, 2, 0]`. We would represent the sparse vector as `avals = [2, 1]` and `aix = [1, 4]` and we only want to do a sequential scan over A. The two-pass approach would then simply initialize the output C as `xor(0, B) = (B!=0)` to capture all zeros of A, which gives us `C = [1, 1, 0, 1, 0]`. Subsequently, we scan A and compute `xor(A,B)` over the non-zeros in A, which overwrites indexes 1 and 4 in C, resulting in the correct output `[1, 0, 0, 1, 0]`.

Let me know if you need help, otherwise I think we should go through this via reviews until everything is fixed in order to get you more familiar with the internals.

well, all combinations of sparse and dense are relevant but its more common to have sparse (filters), at least in the applications I've seen so far.

This operation is actually nothing else than `(X > 0) * dout` but Niketan added an operator to avoid the allocation and materialization of the intermediate. Once codegen is enabled by default (and supported by the GPU backend), we could actually remove this custom fused operators. If you like, you can start with SYSTEMML-2110 that aims to support relu_backward in codegen (in row and cell templates, simply compiled to > and * operations at CPlan level).

well right, there is no need for any of these extensions - just add the tests and a TODO comment to `BinaryOp.constructLopsBinaryDefault` (line 662) to remove RELU_BACKWARD once codegen is supported for GPUs as well. The reason is that relu_backward was not added as a hop rewrite but a hop-lop rewrite, which means its not even visible during codegen.

However, can you please add a random automated gradient test in the `nn/test/gradcheck.dml` in the style of those tests?  The overall idea is that the forward functions can be compared to another implementation for correctness, and then the gradient tests can be automated for random values to ensure that the backward functions are correct w.r.t. their corresponding forward functions.

> Add gradient tests in `nn/test/gradcheck.dml`. The ReLU test can be copied and adapted for the ELU function, and the affine layer test could be copied and adapted for the PReLU. These will ensure that the backward functions are computing the correct derivatives.

yes, the reason is that we use a row-wise default reshape while R uses a column-wise reshape. This was a conscious decision because we internally use row-major representations while R uses column-major formats. You can simply fix your R script via 
`X = matrix(seq(1, 6000)/600, 300, 20, byrow=TRUE);`
instead of 
`X = matrix(seq(1, 6000)/600, 300, 20);`

While you are at it, could you also remove the other merged changes. Thanks.
